skull.brief: Protects the brain and houses sensory organs.
skull.innervation: Trigeminal nerve (sensory branches) and various motor branches for mastication muscles
skull.action: Protective bony vault for the brain; provides attachment for facial muscles
skull.clinicalPearl: Basilar skull fractures may present with raccoon eyes or Battle's sign — inspect carefully.

jaw.brief: Lower jaw bone - largest and strongest facial bone.
jaw.origin: Forms from Meckel's cartilage during development
jaw.insertion: Articulates with temporal bone at temporomandibular joint (TMJ)
jaw.innervation: Inferior alveolar nerve (branch of mandibular division of trigeminal)
jaw.clinicalPearl: Mandibular fractures are the second most common facial fracture after nasal bones. Check for malocclusion, step deformity, and numbness in the lower lip.

clavicle.brief: S-shaped bone connecting the shoulder to the axial skeleton.
clavicle.origin: Medial end articulates with manubrium of sternum
clavicle.insertion: Lateral end articulates with acromion of scapula
clavicle.action: Strut connecting upper limb to trunk, protects neurovascular bundle
clavicle.clinicalPearl: Most commonly fractured bone in children. Falls on outstretched hand (FOOSH) cause fractures typically at the middle third. Check for tenting of skin and neurovascular compromise.

scapula.brief: Flat triangular bone on the posterior thorax.
scapula.origin: Spine, acromion, and coracoid process provide attachment sites
scapula.insertion: Glenoid fossa articulates with humeral head
scapula.innervation: Dorsal scapular nerve, suprascapular nerve, axillary nerve
scapula.action: Provides attachment for shoulder muscles, enables arm movement
scapula.clinicalPearl: Scapular winging indicates serratus anterior weakness (long thoracic nerve injury). Check by having patient push against a wall.

spine.brief: Supports the body and protects the spinal cord.
spine.innervation: Spinal nerves (31 pairs) exiting between vertebrae
spine.action: Axial support, load bearing, movement and neural protection
spine.clinicalPearl: Loss of vertebral height or step deformity on exam suggests compression fractures — check imaging.

ribs.brief: Form the rib cage to protect thoracic organs.
ribs.insertion: Anteriorly to the sternum (true ribs) or via costal cartilage (false ribs)
ribs.innervation: Intercostal nerves (ventral rami of thoracic spinal nerves)
ribs.action: Protection of thoracic organs and assistance with respiration
ribs.clinicalPearl: Flail chest (multiple adjacent rib fractures) can cause paradoxical chest wall motion; consider analgesia and respiratory support.

sternum.brief: Midline breastbone connecting the rib cage.
sternum.origin: Manubrium, body, xiphoid process (components of the sternum)
sternum.action: Central anchor for ribs and thoracic muscles
sternum.clinicalPearl: Sternal fractures commonly result from high-energy anterior chest trauma; evaluate for cardiac contusion if suspected.

humerus.origin: Proximal articulations with the scapula (glenohumeral joint)
humerus.insertion: Distally with radius and ulna at the elbow
humerus.action: Upper limb movement and force transmission
humerus.clinicalPearl: Proximal humeral fractures are common in older adults after a fall; check axillary nerve function (shoulder abduction) and vascular status.

radius.origin: Proximally articulates with humerus and ulna
radius.insertion: Distally forms part of the wrist (carpal bones)
radius.innervation: Radial and median nerve contributions to surrounding muscles
radius.action: Forearm rotation and load transmission to wrist
radius.clinicalPearl: Distal radius (Colles') fractures often occur from FOOSH; check for dinner-fork deformity.

ulna.brief: Medial forearm bone important for elbow stability.
ulna.insertion: Distally forms part of wrist articulation with radius
ulna.innervation: Ulnar nerve supplies intrinsic hand muscles and sensation medially
ulna.action: Forms hinge of elbow and stabilises forearm
ulna.clinicalPearl: Ulnar nerve injury at the elbow causes numbness/tingling in the little finger and weakness in finger abduction/adduction.

femur.brief: Thigh bone — longest and strongest bone.
femur.origin: Proximal articulation with pelvis at the hip
femur.innervation: Femoral nerve (anterior compartment) and sciatic nerve contributions
femur.clinicalPearl: A fractured femoral neck in older adults is an orthopedic emergency — stabilise and arrange urgent orthopedics.

tibia.brief: Shin bone — main weight-bearing bone of the lower leg.
tibia.insertion: Distal tibia forms ankle joint with talus
tibia.innervation: Tibial nerve for posterior compartment muscles
tibia.action: Weight bearing and forming knee/ankle joints
tibia.clinicalPearl: Tibial plateau fractures may impair knee stability — assess joint line tenderness and consider imaging with CT for surgical planning.

fibula.brief: Lateral lower-leg bone providing muscular attachment.
fibula.innervation: Common peroneal (fibular) nerve supplies associated muscles
fibula.action: Provides lateral support and muscle attachment; minor weight bearing
fibula.clinicalPearl: An isolated fibular head fracture may be associated with common peroneal nerve injury; examine dorsiflexion and sensation over the dorsum of the foot.

patella.brief: Kneecap — sesamoid bone in the quadriceps tendon.
patella.action: Protects knee joint and increases lever arm of quadriceps
patella.clinicalPearl: Patellar dislocation typically presents with lateral displacement and may require reduction; check extensor mechanism integrity.

pectoralis.brief: Large chest muscle involved in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
pectoralis.insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus of humerus
pectoralis.action: Adduction, internal rotation and flexion of humerus
pectoralis.clinicalPearl: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.

pectoralis_major.brief: Large chest muscle involved in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
pectoralis_major.insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular sulcus of humerus
pectoralis_major.action: Adduction, internal rotation and flexion of humerus
pectoralis_major.clinicalPearl: Pectoralis major tendon ruptures are seen with heavy lifting; sudden pain and weakness on adduction should raise suspicion. The 'dropped nipple sign' may be visible.

pectoralis_minor.brief: Small chest muscle deep to pectoralis major.
pectoralis_minor.action: Stabilizes scapula by drawing it forward and downward
pectoralis_minor.clinicalPearl: Can compress brachial plexus and subclavian vessels causing thoracic outlet syndrome symptoms.

rotator_cuff.brief: Group of four muscles stabilizing the shoulder joint (SITS).
rotator_cuff.origin: Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres minor from scapula; Subscapularis from subscapular fossa
rotator_cuff.insertion: All insert on humerus forming the rotator cuff around glenohumeral joint
rotator_cuff.innervation: Suprascapular nerve (supra/infraspinatus), axillary nerve (teres minor), subscapular nerves
rotator_cuff.action: Stabilize humeral head in glenoid fossa; initiate abduction, external/internal rotation
rotator_cuff.clinicalPearl: Supraspinatus is most commonly torn. Test with 'empty can test' (painful arc 60-120°). MRI is gold standard for diagnosis. Chronic tears may lead to arthropathy.

masseter.brief: Powerful muscle of mastication elevating the jaw.
masseter.insertion: Lateral surface of mandibular ramus and angle
masseter.innervation: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3)
masseter.clinicalPearl: Masseter hypertrophy can cause 'square jaw' appearance. Assess for bruxism (teeth grinding). Trismus indicates inflammation or tetanus.

deltoid.origin: Lateral third of clavicle, acromion and spine of scapula
deltoid.action: Abduction, flexion, extension and rotation of the arm depending on fibres
deltoid.clinicalPearl: Axillary nerve injury from shoulder dislocation causes deltoid weakness and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).

biceps.brief: Anterior arm muscle for elbow flexion and supination.
biceps.origin: Long head from supraglenoid tubercle; short head from coracoid process
biceps.clinicalPearl: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.

biceps_brachii.brief: Anterior arm muscle for elbow flexion and supination.
biceps_brachii.origin: Long head from supraglenoid tubercle; short head from coracoid process
biceps_brachii.clinicalPearl: Biceps tendon rupture may present with a 'Popeye' deformity and weakness of supination.

quadriceps.brief: Anterior thigh muscle group for knee extension.
quadriceps.origin: Various heads from femur and iliac spine
quadriceps.insertion: Patella via quadriceps tendon to tibial tuberosity
quadriceps.action: Knee extension and hip flexion (rectus femoris)
quadriceps.clinicalPearl: Quadriceps tendon rupture results in inability to actively extend the knee; examine for suprapatellar gap.

gastrocnemius.action: Plantarflexion of the foot and knee flexion
gastrocnemius.clinicalPearl: Achilles tendon rupture commonly presents with a snapping sensation and difficulty with push-off; Thompson test can help diagnosis.

triceps.brief: Posterior arm muscle for elbow extension.
triceps.origin: Long head from infraglenoid tubercle; lateral and medial heads from humerus
triceps.action: Elbow extension and shoulder adduction (long head)
triceps.clinicalPearl: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.

triceps_brachii.brief: Posterior arm muscle for elbow extension.
triceps_brachii.origin: Long head from infraglenoid tubercle; lateral and medial heads from humerus
triceps_brachii.action: Elbow extension and shoulder adduction (long head)
triceps_brachii.clinicalPearl: Radial nerve palsy causes wrist drop and inability to extend the elbow or wrist.

latissimus_dorsi.brief: Large back muscle for shoulder adduction and extension.
latissimus_dorsi.origin: Lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae, sacrum, iliac crest
latissimus_dorsi.action: Adduction, extension, and internal rotation of shoulder
latissimus_dorsi.clinicalPearl: Used in breast reconstruction surgery as a myocutaneous flap. Test by having patient cough.

trapezius.brief: Large superficial back muscle for scapular movement.
trapezius.origin: Occipital bone, nuchal ligament, spinous processes C7-T12
trapezius.insertion: Lateral clavicle, acromion, spine of scapula
trapezius.clinicalPearl: Spinal accessory nerve injury causes shoulder droop and inability to shrug. Can occur iatrogenically during neck surgery.

rectus_abdominis.action: Trunk flexion and compression of abdominal contents
rectus_abdominis.clinicalPearl: Diastasis recti is separation of the rectus abdominis, common in pregnancy. Grey Turner's sign (flank bruising) suggests retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

external_oblique.brief: Lateral abdominal muscle for trunk rotation.
external_oblique.action: Trunk flexion, lateral bending, and contralateral rotation
external_oblique.clinicalPearl: Forms the inguinal ligament and superficial inguinal ring. Important in inguinal hernia anatomy.

gluteus_maximus.brief: Largest buttock muscle for hip extension.
gluteus_maximus.insertion: Iliotibial tract and gluteal tuberosity of femur
gluteus_maximus.action: Hip extension, lateral rotation, and stabilization
gluteus_maximus.clinicalPearl: Trendelenburg gait (hip drop on contralateral side) indicates superior gluteal nerve injury affecting gluteus medius/minimus, not maximus.

hamstrings.brief: Posterior thigh muscle group for knee flexion.
hamstrings.clinicalPearl: Hamstring strains are common in sprinting. Proximal avulsion injuries can occur with violent hip flexion during knee extension.

soleus.action: Plantarflexion of foot (especially when knee is flexed)
soleus.clinicalPearl: Deep to gastrocnemius, forms the triceps surae. Important in venous return ('peripheral heart').

serratus_anterior.brief: Lateral chest muscle that protracts the scapula.
serratus_anterior.clinicalPearl: Long thoracic nerve injury causes winged scapula. Test by having patient push against wall.

tibialis_anterior.brief: Anterior lower leg muscle for dorsiflexion.
tibialis_anterior.insertion: Medial cuneiform and first metatarsal base
tibialis_anterior.clinicalPearl: Foot drop indicates deep peroneal nerve or L5 nerve root injury. Test by asking patient to walk on heels.

brachioradialis.clinicalPearl: Tests radial nerve C5-C6 function. Diminished brachioradialis reflex suggests C6 radiculopathy.

sartorius.brief: Longest muscle in body, crosses hip and knee.
sartorius.action: Hip flexion, abduction, lateral rotation; knee flexion
sartorius.clinicalPearl: Crosses both hip and knee joints. Forms part of pes anserinus with gracilis and semitendinosus.

iliopsoas.brief: Primary hip flexor muscle (iliacus + psoas major).
iliopsoas.clinicalPearl: Psoas abscess causes hip flexion contracture and fever. Positive psoas sign suggests appendicitis.

adductors.brief: Medial thigh muscle group for hip adduction.
adductors.clinicalPearl: Adductor strains common in athletes. Obturator nerve injury causes weakness in hip adduction.

erector_spinae.brief: Deep back muscle group for spine extension.
erector_spinae.action: Spine extension, lateral bending, and postural control
erector_spinae.clinicalPearl: Paraspinal muscle spasm common in low back pain. Includes iliocostalis, longissimus, and spinalis.
